title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 16 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Corinthians chapter 16 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 16 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Corinthians Chapter 16.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 16:2, on which day of the week should believers lay by in store?
options: The first day of the week
The third day of the week
The last day of the week
questions.correctAnswer: The first day of the week
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 16:2 instructs believers to lay by in store upon the first day of the week.

questions.question: Who does Paul say should bring the liberality unto Jerusalem, as mentioned in 1 Corinthians 16:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Those approved by letters
questions.explanation: Paul states in 1 Corinthians 16:3 that he will send those whom the Corinthians approve by their letters to bring the liberality unto Jerusalem.

questions.question: Where does Paul say he will tarry until Pentecost, according to 1 Corinthians 16:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Ephesus
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 16:8 says that Paul will tarry at Ephesus until Pentecost.

questions.question: What does Paul describe as being 'a great door and effectual' in 1 Corinthians 16:9?
questions.correctAnswer: The opportunity for ministry
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 16:9, Paul refers to 'a great door and effectual' as an open opportunity for his ministry.

questions.question: What does Paul urge the Corinthians to do in 1 Corinthians 16:13?
options: Watch, stand fast in the faith, quit you like men, be strong
questions.correctAnswer: Watch, stand fast in the faith, quit you like men, be strong
questions.explanation: Paul exhorts the Corinthians in 1 Corinthians 16:13 to watch, stand fast in the faith, act courageously, and be strong.

questions.question: Who does Paul mention as having supplied what was lacking on the Corinthians' part in 1 Corinthians 16:17?
questions.correctAnswer: Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 16:17, Paul expresses gladness for the coming of Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus because they supplied what was lacking on the Corinthians' part.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 16:19, who sends salutations to the Corinthians?
options: The churches of Asia, Aquila and Priscilla
questions.correctAnswer: The churches of Asia, Aquila and Priscilla
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 16:19 states that the churches of Asia, along with Aquila and Priscilla, send salutations to the Corinthians.

questions.question: What greeting does Paul instruct believers to use with one another in 1 Corinthians 16:20?
questions.correctAnswer: An holy kiss
questions.explanation: Paul instructs the believers in 1 Corinthians 16:20 to greet one another with an holy kiss.

questions.question: Who does Paul say works the work of the Lord without fear in 1 Corinthians 16:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Timotheus
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 16:10 speaks of Timotheus as one who works the work of the Lord without fear.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 16:12, why did Apollos not come to the Corinthians at that time?
options: His will was not at all to come at that time
questions.correctAnswer: His will was not at all to come at that time
questions.explanation: Paul states in 1 Corinthians 16:12 that Apollos' will was not to come at that time but he would come when convenient.

questions.question: True or False: In 1 Corinthians 16:22, Paul says if anyone does not love the Lord Jesus Christ, let him be Anathema Maranatha.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 16:22 clearly states that if anyone does not love the Lord Jesus Christ, let him be Anathema Maranatha.

questions.question: True or False: Paul mentions that he will not see the Corinthians by the way but hopes to tarry with them if the Lord permits, according to 1 Corinthians 16:7.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 16:7 says Paul will not see them by the way but trusts to tarry a while with them if the Lord permit.

questions.question: True or False: In 1 Corinthians 16:14, Paul instructs that all things should be done with charity.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Paul commands in 1 Corinthians 16:14 that all things be done with charity.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Corinthians 16:23: 'The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: with you
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 16:23 ends with 'The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Corinthians 16:15: 'I beseech you, brethren, (ye know the house of ________), that it is the firstfruits of Achaia.'
questions.correctAnswer: Stephanas
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 16:15 refers to the house of Stephanas as the firstfruits of Achaia.

medium.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 16 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Corinthians Chapter 16 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 16 teach us about the importance of regular giving and stewardship?
options: By setting aside a sum on the first day of the week according to one’s prosperity
By giving only when the church calls for a collection
By giving sporadically during special feasts
By giving only after receiving personal blessings
questions.correctAnswer: By setting aside a sum on the first day of the week according to one’s prosperity
questions.explanation: Verse 2 instructs believers to lay by in store on the first day of the week as God prospers them, indicating disciplined, regular giving (1 Corinthians 16:2). This is supported by the orderly collection Paul mentions in verses 1 and 3.

questions.question: A fellow believer is hesitant to serve in the church because of fear. Based on 1 Corinthians 16, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Serve without fear because God’s work is honorable
Wait until you feel completely confident before serving
Serve only when asked by church leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Serve without fear because God’s work is honorable
questions.explanation: Paul encourages the church to receive Timothy without fear because he works for the Lord (1 Corinthians 16:10-11). This teaches believers to serve courageously and faithfully.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 16:13 teach about perseverance and courage in the Christian life?
options: Watch, stand fast in the faith, quit you like men, be strong
Depend on others to lead you always
Ignore your faith in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: Watch, stand fast in the faith, quit you like men, be strong
questions.explanation: Verse 13 calls believers to vigilance, steadfastness, courage, and strength, encouraging perseverance through trials with faith and boldness.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 16, how should all things be done in the Christian community?
questions.correctAnswer: With charity (love)
questions.explanation: Verse 14 clearly states that all actions should be done with love, emphasizing that love is central to Christian conduct.

questions.question: In the context of church fellowship, what does Paul urge believers to do concerning those who serve and labor among them?
options: Submit to them and recognize their labor
questions.correctAnswer: Submit to them and recognize their labor
questions.explanation: Verses 15-16 instruct believers to submit to those who help and labor among them, promoting unity and respect within the church body.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 16 show the importance of mutual encouragement among believers?
options: By acknowledging those who refresh the spirit of others
By focusing only on personal spiritual growth
By isolating oneself to avoid distractions
By avoiding fellowship to prevent conflict
questions.correctAnswer: By acknowledging those who refresh the spirit of others
questions.explanation: Verses 17-18 highlight that Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus refreshed Paul's spirit and the Corinthians’, showing the vital role of encouragement and support.

questions.question: What practical advice does 1 Corinthians 16 give about greeting one another in the church?
options: Greet one another with a holy kiss
Avoid physical greetings to keep distance
questions.correctAnswer: Greet one another with a holy kiss
questions.explanation: Verse 20 encourages believers to greet one another with a holy kiss, symbolizing affection and unity within the Christian fellowship.

questions.question: Based on 1 Corinthians 16, what is the proper attitude toward someone who does not love the Lord Jesus Christ?
options: Try to please them for peace
questions.correctAnswer: Let him be Anathema Maranatha
questions.explanation: Verse 22 uses strong language to denote separation from those who do not love Christ, emphasizing the seriousness of rejecting Jesus.

questions.question: True or False: Paul planned to stay in Ephesus until Pentecost, as stated in 1 Corinthians 16.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 8 explicitly states that Paul would remain in Ephesus until Pentecost, showing his intention to remain there for a season.

questions.question: True or False: Apollos immediately agreed to visit the Corinthians when Paul requested him, according to 1 Corinthians 16.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 12 reveals that Apollos was unwilling to come at that time but planned to come when convenient, showing his own timing decision.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Paul asks the Corinthians to lay by in store upon the first day of the week, as God hath ______ him.
questions.correctAnswer: prospered
questions.explanation: Verse 2 instructs believers to set aside an amount according to how God has prospered them, emphasizing stewardship based on God’s provision.

questions.question: What can we learn about trusting God’s timing from Paul’s travel plans in 1 Corinthians 16?
options: Trust the Lord’s permission before making plans
Make plans without considering God’s will
questions.correctAnswer: Trust the Lord’s permission before making plans
questions.explanation: Verse 7 shows Paul’s trust in the Lord’s permission to tarry with them, teaching believers to depend on God’s timing in their plans.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 16 emphasize the role of ministry and service within the church?
options: By commending Stephanas and his household for dedicating themselves to the ministry of the saints
By discouraging active involvement in ministry
By limiting ministry to only apostles
By focusing on personal spirituality only
questions.correctAnswer: By commending Stephanas and his household for dedicating themselves to the ministry of the saints
questions.explanation: Verse 15 praises Stephanas’ household for their devoted service, highlighting the value of ministry in practical church life.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 16 illustrate the importance of supporting church leaders and workers?
options: By instructing believers to submit to those who labor among them
questions.correctAnswer: By instructing believers to submit to those who labor among them
questions.explanation: Verse 16 calls for submission to those who help and labor in the church, promoting unity and respect for ministry efforts.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 16, what is the significance of Paul sending approved men to Jerusalem with the collection?
options: To ensure orderly and trustworthy handling of the offering
To delay the delivery of funds
questions.correctAnswer: To ensure orderly and trustworthy handling of the offering
questions.explanation: Verses 3-4 show Paul’s desire to send approved men with letters to carry the collection, emphasizing integrity and accountability in giving.

hard.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 16 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Corinthians Chapter 16.

questions.question: What instruction does Paul give concerning the collection for the saints, and how does it reflect his pastoral strategy?
options: Each church should collect offerings on the first day of the week, as he ordered the churches of Galatia
Collections should be made during festival days only
Each member should give spontaneously without set times
questions.correctAnswer: Each church should collect offerings on the first day of the week, as he ordered the churches of Galatia
questions.explanation: Paul instructs that the collection should be done on the first day of the week, mirroring his prior instructions to the Galatian churches, indicating an orderly and planned approach to giving (1 Corinthians 16:1-2). This reflects early Christian communal support and echoes Jewish practices of weekly sacred assemblies.

questions.question: Why does Paul emphasize that there be 'no gatherings when I come' in relation to the collection?
options: To avoid embarrassment or pressure on the believers when giving
To prevent theft of the offerings
Because he prefers to collect personally
To ensure the collection is done secretly
questions.correctAnswer: To avoid embarrassment or pressure on the believers when giving
questions.explanation: Paul's instruction to lay by in store so there are no gatherings when he arrives suggests a desire to avoid any undue pressure or awkwardness in the act of giving, emphasizing voluntary and thoughtful generosity (1 Corinthians 16:2). This reflects a pastoral sensitivity uncommon in Greco-Roman patronage systems.

questions.question: Who does Paul intend to send to Jerusalem to deliver the collection, and what is the significance of approval by letters?
options: Those approved by the Corinthians through letters, ensuring accountability
Any traveling apostle available at the time
Timothy only, as a trusted delegate
questions.correctAnswer: Those approved by the Corinthians through letters, ensuring accountability
questions.explanation: Paul plans to send delegates who are approved by the Corinthians with letters, establishing a formal authorization mechanism that ensured trust and accountability in the transfer of funds to Jerusalem (1 Corinthians 16:3). This system reflects early church administrative order and foreshadows later epistolary protocols.

questions.question: What does Paul's plan to possibly travel with those carrying the collection reveal about his mission strategy?
options: He would accompany the delegates if it was fitting, indicating solidarity and oversight
He prefers to stay in Ephesus alone
He avoids traveling to dangerous places
He intends to delegate all responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: He would accompany the delegates if it was fitting, indicating solidarity and oversight
questions.explanation: Paul indicates that if it is fitting, he will go with the delegates to Jerusalem, showing a commitment to personal involvement and oversight in the collection delivery, which underscores the importance of unity and support among early believers (1 Corinthians 16:4).

questions.question: What does Paul's mention of passing through Macedonia and possibly wintering with the Corinthians suggest about early Christian travel and hospitality?
options: Early Christian travel depended on local hospitality and community support
Travel was strictly for preaching only
Wintering was avoided due to dangers
questions.correctAnswer: Early Christian travel depended on local hospitality and community support
questions.explanation: Paul’s plan to pass through Macedonia and possibly stay over winter with the Corinthians highlights the reliance on local churches' hospitality and the communal nature of early Christian mission work, reflecting the socio-cultural context of itinerant ministry in the ancient world (1 Corinthians 16:5-6).

questions.question: Paul states he will tarry at Ephesus until Pentecost. What is the significance of this timing?
options: Pentecost, a Jewish festival, is a significant time for ministry and connects Jewish and Christian traditions
Pentecost was a Roman holiday unrelated to the church
He planned to avoid Pentecost festivals
Pentecost was the start of the new year
questions.correctAnswer: Pentecost, a Jewish festival, is a significant time for ministry and connects Jewish and Christian traditions
questions.explanation: By choosing to remain at Ephesus until Pentecost, Paul aligns his ministry with a major Jewish festival, symbolizing the continuity and fulfillment of Jewish festivals in Christian practice and indicating strategic timing for outreach and teaching (1 Corinthians 16:8).

questions.question: What does Paul mean by 'a great door and effectual is opened unto me' at Ephesus, and how does this relate to his ministry challenges?
options: He has a significant opportunity for effective ministry despite many adversaries
He has been imprisoned and restricted
He is able to open literal doors for gatherings
He is planning to close the church temporarily
questions.correctAnswer: He has a significant opportunity for effective ministry despite many adversaries
questions.explanation: The metaphor of an 'open door' signifies a promising opportunity for evangelism and teaching in Ephesus, while acknowledging the presence of many adversaries, reflecting the tension and opposition often faced in early Christian mission (1 Corinthians 16:9).

questions.question: What characteristic of Timothy's work does Paul emphasize, and why is this important for the Corinthian church's reception of him?
options: Timothy works the work of the Lord without fear, deserving respect and peace
Timothy is a skilled orator only
Timothy has a political role in the church
questions.correctAnswer: Timothy works the work of the Lord without fear, deserving respect and peace
questions.explanation: Paul encourages the Corinthians to receive Timothy without fear because he is diligently working for the Lord, underscoring the importance of fearlessness and dedication in ministry and urging the community to support such workers (1 Corinthians 16:10-11).

questions.question: How does Paul's mention of Apollos' delayed visit illustrate early church dynamics and personal agency?
options: Apollos chooses the timing of his visit, showing respect for personal decision
Apollos is forced to stay away due to conflict
Apollos is unable to travel for health reasons
questions.correctAnswer: Apollos chooses the timing of his visit, showing respect for personal decision
questions.explanation: Paul notes that Apollos was unwilling to come at that time but will visit when convenient, highlighting respect for personal agency within ministry and the flexible nature of early church leadership (1 Corinthians 16:12).

questions.question: Which exhortation in 1 Corinthians 16:13 employs a military metaphor, and what does it imply about the believers' conduct?
options: 'Quit you like men' implying courage and steadfastness in faith amidst challenges
'Watch ye' meaning be vigilant against physical enemies only
questions.correctAnswer: 'Quit you like men' implying courage and steadfastness in faith amidst challenges
questions.explanation: The phrase 'quit you like men' uses a military metaphor urging believers to act courageously and firmly in their faith, emphasizing spiritual strength and perseverance (1 Corinthians 16:13).

questions.question: How does the Greek word translated as 'charity' in 1 Corinthians 16:14 connect to the broader New Testament theme of love?
options: It is 'agape,' denoting selfless, sacrificial love as the foundation of Christian conduct
questions.correctAnswer: It is 'agape,' denoting selfless, sacrificial love as the foundation of Christian conduct
questions.explanation: The term 'charity' in this verse is the Greek 'agape,' which represents unconditional, self-giving love that is central to Christian ethics and is a recurring theme throughout the New Testament (1 Corinthians 16:14).

questions.question: What role do the household of Stephanas and others play in the early church according to Paul's description?
options: They are the firstfruits of Achaia and have devoted themselves to ministering to the saints
They are wealthy patrons funding Paul's travels
They are opponents of the gospel
They are solely responsible for building the church structures
questions.correctAnswer: They are the firstfruits of Achaia and have devoted themselves to ministering to the saints
questions.explanation: Paul refers to the household of Stephanas as the first converts in Achaia who have committed themselves to the ministry of serving fellow believers, illustrating early models of dedicated Christian service (1 Corinthians 16:15).

questions.question: Why does Paul urge the Corinthians to submit to those who labor with the church, and how does this reflect early church authority structures?
options: Because submission fosters unity and respects those who work hard for the gospel
Because submission was legally enforced by Roman authorities
Because submission was a cultural norm only in Corinth
questions.correctAnswer: Because submission fosters unity and respects those who work hard for the gospel
questions.explanation: Paul encourages submission to those who labor, highlighting the value of respect and cooperation in maintaining church order and unity, reflecting an early form of ecclesiastical authority based on service and labor (1 Corinthians 16:16).

questions.question: What is the significance of Paul's statement 'If any man love not the Lord Jesus Christ, let him be Anathema Maranatha'?
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Paul pronounces a solemn curse and calls for the Lord's coming judgment against those who do not love Christ, using the Aramaic terms 'Anathema' (accursed) and 'Maranatha' (Our Lord, come), emphasizing the serious consequences of rejecting Jesus (1 Corinthians 16:22).

questions.question: Who sends greetings to the Corinthian church, and what does this reveal about early Christian fellowship?
options: The churches of Asia, Aquila and Priscilla, and the brethren, indicating interconnectedness among early churches
questions.correctAnswer: The churches of Asia, Aquila and Priscilla, and the brethren, indicating interconnectedness among early churches
questions.explanation: Paul mentions greetings from the churches of Asia, Aquila and Priscilla, and all the brethren, illustrating the network of relationships and mutual support among early Christian communities (1 Corinthians 16:19-20).

theological.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 16 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Corinthians Chapter 16 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What specific instruction does Paul give regarding the collection for the saints?
options: Each one should lay by in store on the first day of the week, as God has prospered him
Give whenever you feel moved by the Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Each one should lay by in store on the first day of the week, as God has prospered him
questions.explanation: Paul instructs in 1 Corinthians 16:2 that on the first day of the week, each believer is to set aside a sum of money as he prospers, to avoid collections when Paul comes. This teaches orderly giving according to God's blessing, consistent with 2 Corinthians 9:7, Proverbs 3:9, Malachi 3:10, and Exodus 25:2.

questions.question: Who does Paul say will be approved by letters to deliver the collection to Jerusalem?
options: Whomsoever you approve by your letters
questions.correctAnswer: Whomsoever you approve by your letters
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 16:3, Paul mentions that those approved by the Corinthians through letters will be sent to bring the liberality to Jerusalem, showing the importance of accountability and church order. This aligns with Acts 15:22 and 2 Corinthians 8:23 concerning trustworthy ministry.

questions.question: According to Paul, where will he stay until Pentecost?
questions.correctAnswer: Ephesus
questions.explanation: Paul states in 1 Corinthians 16:8 that he will remain in Ephesus until Pentecost, indicating his strategic ministry timing, consistent with Acts 19:1-41 and the significance of Pentecost in Jewish and early Christian eschatology (Leviticus 23:15-21, Acts 2:1-4).

questions.question: What reason does Paul give for the 'great door and effectual' being opened to him?
options: He is popular among the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: There are many adversaries
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 16:9, Paul notes that a great and effective door for ministry has opened to him, but there are many adversaries, highlighting the tension between gospel opportunity and spiritual opposition. This theme echoes Acts 14:27, 2 Corinthians 2:12, and Ephesians 6:12.

questions.question: How does Paul describe Timothy's work among the believers?
options: He works the work of the Lord without fear
questions.correctAnswer: He works the work of the Lord without fear
questions.explanation: Paul encourages the Corinthians to receive Timothy without fear because he works the work of the Lord, as stated in 1 Corinthians 16:10. This reflects Timothy’s faithful ministry and courage, consistent with Acts 16:1-3, 2 Timothy 1:7, and Philippians 2:19-22.

questions.question: What does Paul urge the Corinthians to do concerning Apollos?
options: Understand that he will come when convenient
Rebuke him for not coming now
Send him a letter of rebuke
questions.correctAnswer: Understand that he will come when convenient
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 16:12, Paul explains that Apollos does not intend to come now but will visit at a suitable time, indicating respect for his autonomy and timing, consistent with Acts 18:24-28 and Romans 16:12.

questions.question: Which exhortation does Paul give in verse 13 about Christian conduct?
options: Watch, stand fast in the faith, quit you like men, be strong
Trust in worldly wisdom for strength
questions.correctAnswer: Watch, stand fast in the faith, quit you like men, be strong
questions.explanation: Paul commands vigilance, steadfastness in faith, courage, and strength in 1 Corinthians 16:13, reflecting the call to spiritual maturity found in Ephesians 6:10-18, 1 Peter 5:8-9, Joshua 1:9, and Psalm 27:14.

questions.question: What principle does Paul emphasize for all actions in verse 14?
options: Let all your things be done with charity
questions.correctAnswer: Let all your things be done with charity
questions.explanation: Paul instructs that everything should be done with love (charity) in 1 Corinthians 16:14, underscoring the centrality of agape love in Christian ethics, consistent with 1 Corinthians 13, John 13:34-35, and 1 John 4:7-8.

questions.question: Who does Paul commend for their ministry to the saints in verse 15?
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Stephanas
questions.explanation: Paul mentions the household of Stephanas as the firstfruits of Achaia who devoted themselves to the ministry of the saints (1 Corinthians 16:15), highlighting faithful service consistent with Romans 16:3-5 and Acts 18:2-3.

questions.question: What attitude does Paul urge the Corinthians to have toward those who labor with the ministry?
questions.correctAnswer: Submit to and acknowledge them
questions.explanation: In verses 16 and 18, Paul urges submission to and recognition of those who labor in ministry, emphasizing unity and respect within the church body, in harmony with Hebrews 13:17, 1 Thessalonians 5:12-13, and Romans 13:1-7.

questions.question: Which form of greeting does Paul instruct the Corinthians to use among themselves?
options: Greet one another with a holy kiss
questions.correctAnswer: Greet one another with a holy kiss
questions.explanation: Paul commands in 1 Corinthians 16:20 to greet one another with a holy kiss, a cultural expression of Christian love and fellowship, supported by Romans 16:16, 2 Corinthians 13:12, and 1 Thessalonians 5:26.

questions.question: What solemn warning does Paul give to those who do not love the Lord Jesus Christ?
options: They will be praised among men
They will be blessed by God
questions.correctAnswer: Let him be Anathema Maranatha
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 16:22, Paul pronounces anathema, meaning accursed, on those who do not love the Lord, combining a curse and an eschatological invocation ('Maranatha' - 'The Lord is coming'), affirming the essential Christocentric love required in salvation, consistent with John 3:36, Romans 8:38-39, and Revelation 22:20.

questions.question: What blessing does Paul pronounce upon the Corinthians in verse 23?
options: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you
questions.correctAnswer: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you
questions.explanation: Paul’s benediction in 1 Corinthians 16:23 invokes the grace of Jesus Christ, emphasizing unmerited favor as the foundation of Christian life, aligning with Romans 1:7, 2 Corinthians 13:14, Ephesians 2:8, and Titus 2:11.

questions.question: What is the final expression of Paul’s affection to the believers in verse 24?
options: My love be with you all in Christ Jesus
May you prosper in worldly ways
questions.correctAnswer: My love be with you all in Christ Jesus
questions.explanation: Paul closes with a declaration of love in Christ (1 Corinthians 16:24), underscoring the centrality of Christ as the source of Christian love, supported by Romans 5:5, Galatians 5:6, and 1 John 4:16.

questions.question: Which individuals does Paul mention as having supplied what was lacking on the Corinthians’ part?
questions.correctAnswer: Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus
questions.explanation: Paul expresses joy at the arrival of Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus who supplied what the Corinthians lacked (1 Corinthians 16:17), illustrating mutual support within the early church, consistent with Acts 18:2-3 and Romans 16:23.
